case_data.name: Perez-Perez v. Progressive Forestry Services, Inc.
case_data.plaintiff_description: All persons recruited from Mexico to work for Progressive Forestry Services, Inc. in its 1996/1997 reforestation project
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
In 2000, four migrant reforestation workers, an Oregon labor organization, and one of its members filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court District for the District of Oregon, seeking redress for migrant reforestation workers recruited and employed by farm/forestry labor contractors in Oregon. Plaintiffs alleged that in 1996, defendants recruited and hired workers from Mexico to work in Oregon and in doing so violated the Agricultural Migrant and Seasonal Worker Protection Act, 29 U.S.C. § 1801 et seq. ("AWPA"), and the Oregon Labor Contractors Registration Act, ORS 658.405 et seq. ("OCRA") by charging workers $1000 recruitment fees, visa fees, cost of transportation from Mexico to the U.S. and not paying the full amount of wages due. Plaintiffs sought statutory damages, injunctive relief and class certification.

The District Court (Judge Garr M. King) granted plaintiffs' motion for class certification to address alleged past wrongs, but denied the request for an injunction permanently enjoining defendants from committing future violations. In the same order, the Court granted defendants' partial summary judgment motion and dismissed as plaintiffs the Oregon labor organization and its members. The case proceeded as a class action with the four migrant reforestation workers acting as representative plaintiffs. Perez-Perez v. Progressive Forestry Services, Inc., F.Supp.2d, 2000 WL 40927 (D.Or. Jan. 19, 2000).

According to the PACER docket, the parties reached a settlement. The Court held a fairness hearing on August 26, 2002 and entered a final order approving the settlement on September 16, 2002. The settlement documents were filed by the parties under seal, so the terms of the settlement are unknown.

6  and state laws by charging workers recruitment fees, visa fees, and the cost of transportation 
7  from Mexico to the United States, by not paying the full amount of wages required for the work, 
8  and by committing certain other violations in the course of hiring workers.  Plaintiffs seek to 
9  recover damages on behalf of themselves and on behalf of others similarly situated for those 
lO  violations of law.  Defendants deny each of the claims against them, and to date the Court has 
11  made no ruling that any of these claims are valid or invalid.  By sending you this notice the 
12  Court does not express any opinion about the merits of the claims or defenses of the parties. 
13  This notice is sent to you only to advise you that this action is pending and that you have certain 
14  rights with respect to it. 
15  4.  Exhibit A contains 380 names of those persons whom defendants have identified as 
16  falling within the class definition, although the class may include additional persons.  If your 
17  name appears on the attached or, if you were recruited from Mexico to perform reforestation 
18  work for Progressive Forestry Services between the fall of 1996 and the summer of 1997, and 
19  either you paid or promised to pay a recruitment fee and were transported by defendants or their 
20  agents to the U.S., you will be considered a member of the class unless you ask to be excluded. 
21  Instructions for being excluded are in ~ 5, below.  If you do not ask to be excluded from the 
22  class, you will receive the benefits of a favorable decision and you will be bound by an adverse 
23  decisiun.  This means that if you do not request exclusion and thc plaintiffs win, you will share 
24  in any benefit conferred by the judgment, and if the plaintiffs lose, you will receive no benefit 
25  from the lawsuit and you will not be permitted to litigate any of the claims asserted on behalf of 
26  the class in this lawsuit. If the plaintiffs lose, you will not have to pay for the litigation expenses 
Page 2 - NOTICE OF PENDENCY OF CLASS ACTION 

1  of the defendants.  To be included as a member of the class you need not do anything in response 
2  to this notice (although you should inform the attorneys representing the class as to your current 
3  address, as noted in paragraph 7, below). 
4  5.  If you are excluded from this class you will not share in the benefits of the judgment if 
5  it is favorable to the plaintiffs, and you will not be bound by the judgment if it is adverse to the 
6  plaintiffs.  If you wish to be excluded from the class, you must request exclusion in writing to: 
7  Judge Garr M. King, United States Courthouse, 1000 SW Third Avenue, Portland, OR 97204. 
8  Your request to be excluded must be postmarked by 7th day of March 2002, and should include 
9  the name and number of this case, your name, address and telephone number, and the places and 
10  dates of your work for the defendants.  If you do not request exclusion in a timely manner in 
11  writing, you will automatically be included in the class represented by the plaintiffs. 
12  6.  You also have the right to hire your own lawyer and remain as a member of the class. 
13  That lawyer must appear in this case promptly.

documents.title: Final Order Approving Settlement of Class Action
documents.text:
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
DISTRICT OF OREGON 
MARIO ARNULFO PEREZ-PEREZ  CV 98-1474-KJ 
RAFAEL ARTURO PEREZ-PEREZ 
NICOLAS GONZALEZ-CRUZ 
RAFAEL CHAVEZ-LARA, 
individually and on behalf of all those 
similarly situated, 
Plaintiffs,  FINAL ORDER 
APPROVING SETTLEMENT 
vs.  OF CLASS ACTION 
PROGRESSIVE FORESTRY SERVICES, INC. 
NORTH AMERICAN LABOR MANAGEMENT INC. 
ROBERT WADE ZAHARIE 
BRUCE CAMPBELL 
EFRAIN VALADEZ; 
Defendants. 
This matter came before the Court by the parties' Joint Motion for Preliminary Approval of 
Settlement and Approval of Notice to Class.  By Order of May 29,2002, the Court preliminarily 
approved the terms of the settlement between the parties and approved the form and manner of 
notice to be sent to class members. 
The approved notice has been sent to class members and radio announcements regarding the 
Page 1 - FINAL ORDER APPROVING SETTLEMENT OF CLASS ACTION 

settlement have run in selected states and cities in Mexico; no class members have objected to the 
proposed settlement.  Mr. Mitchell, plaintiffs' financial expert, has reviewed defendants' financial 
records and reported to plaintiffs that he is satisfied with the representations made by the defendants 
regarding their financial condition.  Now, therefore, it is hereby 
ORDERED that the Court finds the settlement between the parties set forth in the Stipulation 
for Settlement is fair, reasonable, and in the best interests of the class and is therefore approved 
under Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(~), and the parties a~dir~cted t'10mply therewith. 
U-u.!J7 
Y  . 20~2. 
DATED this  ;.{,  day of 
"cARRM. KING 
United States District Judge
